summary: the world health organization declared a global influenza pandemic in 2009 when the influenza A (H1N1) pdm09 virus spread rapidly worldwide [1] in Korea, 740,835 patients were confirmed to have pandemic in 2009 and 225 died [2,3] during the pandemic period, some patients were hospitalized in intensive care units (ICU) because of influenza-associated pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). data were collected from all consecutive patients from November 2009 to February 2010 and from November 2015 to March 2016. 57 critically ill patients of Samsung Medical Center and Asan Medical Center in the database included 34 patients with H1N1 acute respiratory failure. this study included 34 patients with H1N1 acute respiratory failure. data were compared by the Mann-Whitney U test for continuous variables and by the Pearson’s exact test for categorical variables. data were analyzed using IBM SPSS Statistics for Windows, version 23.0 (Armonk, NY, USA) 57 critically ill patients of Samsung Medical Center and Asan Medical Center in the database included 34 patients with H1N1 acute respiratory failure. this retrospective study was approved by the institutional review board (IRB) of Samsung Medical Center (IRB application no. 2016-07-137) and Asan Medical Center (IRB application no. 2018–0224) patient information was anonymized and de-identified before analysis. data are presented as the median and interquartile range (IQR) for continuous variables and as frequency (percentage) for categorical variables. data were compared by the Mann-Whitney U test for continuous variables and by the Pearson’s chi-square test. solid organ malignancies were less frequently observed in patients in 2016 than in those in 2009. peramivir was more frequently used in patients diagnosed in 2016 than in those diagnosed in 2009 (93% versus 41%, P = 0.047) six (21%) patients in 2016 and 15 (44%) in 2009 received CRRT. among 15 patients in 2009, four had chronic kidney disease on hemodialysis. four had chronic kidney disease on hemodialysis and two had acute kidney injury without underlying chronic kidney disease. 4 (14) 5 (15) 1.0 Nitric oxide 3 (11) 7 (21) 0.490 CRRT 6 (21)a 15 (44)b 0.060 CRRT in acute kidney injury 2 (7) 9 (27) 0.092 ECMO 6 (21) 5 (15) 0.523 Length of MV, days 7 (4–19) 6 (3–17) 0.571 Length of hospital stay, days 10 (7–28) 8 (5–14) 0.210 Length of hospital stay, days 20 ( 0.17; 95% CI, 0.04–0.81, P = 0.025) and prone positioning (HR, 7.52; 95% CI, 1.37–41.40, P = 0.025) were significantly associated with mortality. univariable and multivariable Cox proportional hazards model cumulative survival curve for patients with H1N1 acute respiratory failure each year. a Cox proportional hazard model was used to determine whether treatment year was associated with in-hospital mortality. the initial clinical variables entered in the model included age, sex, body mass index, year, diabetes mellitus, current or previous solid organ malignancy, neuromuscular blockers, prone positioning, nitric oxide, and CRRT in acute kidney injury. patients treated with ECMO in 2016 had been transferred from outside hospitals on ECMO support. four of the six patients treated with ECMO in 2016 had been transferred from outside hospitals on ECMO support. four patients had chronic kidney disease on hemodialysis, two had chronic kidney disease without hemodialysis, and nine had acute kidney injury, without underlying chronic kidney disease. (5.4 versus 9.2 mL/kg, P = 0.018) and FiO2 (0.5 versus 0.9, P = 0.009) were significantly lower in 2016 than in 2009. in-hospital mortality (17 versus 60%, P = 0.242) was lower in 2016 than in 2009. (7.5–12.3) 0.018 Neuromuscular blocking agent 10 (91) 5 (8 the mortality in this study (18% in 2016 and 44% in 2009) was comparable with the 17.3–41.4% mortality rate reported by previous studies of critically ill patients with H1N1 infection. this improved survival might be related to advances in ICU management. tidal volumes for predicted body weight were significantly lower in patients receiving ECMO in 2016 than in those in 2009. prompt initiation of ECMO treatment should be considered when refractory hypoxia is not relieved by conventional treatment in severe H1N1 pneumonia. treatment outcomes for patients with H1N1 acute respiratory failure improved from 2009 to 2016 in two tertiary referral centers in south Korea. however, the small sample size made our study prone to selection bias.
